page.title: 13Drainage of Mark's Moors
page.content: Like many villages of Somerset,the principal occupation of the inhabitants is farming and it grew up as a market centre for its produce. As can be gathered by the name of the main road-{The Causeway}used to be the only route through the area above water and this is thought to be another reason for the name of the village- the fact that a "Mark was left by the water".Willows were planted to help drainage. The water slowly subsided but even in the 1950 flooding was a real problem tothe farmers who often had to use boats to reach Mark. The 50s saw the start of a new{drainage system}which controls the amount of water in the ditches. The effect of the water was to produce a very acidic soil suitable only for dairy farming. Despite the use of fertilisers,crop yields are poor here.
